newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian Broadcasting Corp Morning Update.
newsitem.headline: Australian Broadcasting Corp Morning Update.

text.p: THREDBO DEATH TOLL STANDS AT 12
The Thredbo landslide death toll has risen to 12 with two more bodies pulled from the rubble last night.
The two male bodies were found as rescue coordinators moved into what they are calling the most dangerous section of the recovery operation, with heavy concrete slabs slowly being removed.
Eight men and four women are among the victims so far accounted for, and six people are still missing.
There has been one survivor of the landslide which caused the collapse of two ski lodges in the New South Wales resort town last Wednesday night.
Meanwhile, rescue workers have been stringing chain mesh across dirt slopes on the site to prevent further landslides when forecast rain hits Thredbo later today.
Police spokeswoman Stephanie Ryan said every effort is being made to prepare for the storm front.
THREE TO FACE COURT OVER DEATH OF BASE JUMPER
Three men will face court later this month, after the death of a man in a base jumping accident at Bungonia Gorge near Goulburn in New South Wales.

Police rescue teams yesterday recovered the body of a man, after his parachute failed to open while base jumping on Monday. It is believed he died instantly but it took rescue personnel more than 20-hours to retrieve his body.
His companions have been charged with engaging in an unsafe act, in contravention of National Parks and Wildlife Service regulations.
FEDERAL GOVERNMENT DOESN'T WANT PEOPLE PAYING MORE TAX
The Federal Government says it does not want people paying more tax if it takes over collection of state tobacco, alcohol and petrol taxes.
The High Court has ruled the State taxes constitutionally invalid.
If all states request the action, the Commonwealth will plug the $5 billion hole in state coffers left by the High Court ruling.
But it will have to levy the taxes at a uniform national rate then pass the revenue back to the states.
That will mean states which had lower rates than the uniform rate will get extra money.
But the Treasurer, Peter Costello, who has acknowledged the solution is complicated, wants the states to pass the excess revenue onto wholesalers.
FORMER PM GOES ONLINE DISCUSSING TRADE AND TECHNOLOGY
Former Prime Minister Paul Keating believes trade and technology policy is as important as defence policy, in ensuring Australia's national survival.
Mr Keating spoke at a company dinner in Sydney last night.
In a rare public appearance, he said Australia must develop its ability to provide information services if it is to continue to grow as a power.
He said improvements in Australian Information Technology potential will also benefit the country internally.

Responding to a question later, Mr Keating said I-T is important in producing jobs, but the only real way to ensure lower levels of unemployment is through all government policy being targeted at increasing levels of economic growth.
Only a few days after the current prime minister, John Howard, launched his Internet site, Mr Keating revealed his own web page last night.
A copy of his speech at the company dinner will be able to be accessed at the site later this morning.
The Keating site can be reached at: www.keating.org.au
